11-12th grade hybrid/remote learning starts tomorrow (check your email for links to Canvas and Zoom invites)
7-12th fully virtual learners start tomorrow as well (check your email for links)

Best wishes to all of our off-site, Early College and Career Center learners as well!

Each year, Stage 32 Seniors who have gone above and beyond and shown true leadership among their peers are inducted into the Stage 32 Hall of Fame, and have their names engraved on a plaque displayed in the Events Lobby at U-32. This year we had 13 amazing students from which to choose. An embarrassment of riches! The 4 students being inducted into this year’s hall of fame have all made their mark on and off the stage, and each one stands out for their sense of humor, bravery, hard work, creativity, spirit of team work, humility and talent. Congratulations to Camille Cheney, James Pacheco, Kate McKay and Charlie Darmstadt. You will be missed but your legacy will live on. 🏆🏆🏆🏆

Friday, May 1st is School Lunch Hero Day.

While school food service staff deserve our thanks and appreciation every day of every year, this year is especially important. Vermont’s school food service heroes are continuing to work in empty schools to keep Vermont’s kids fed during this uncertain time. They report that they really miss seeing their students, and the drawings and notes of appreciation they receive really brighten their day. Teachers and parents are encouraged to suggest that students send their local food service heroes a message of thanks on Friday. Notes can be left on pick-up coolers, shown from car windows, or posted on social media.

Use the hashtags #vted and #SchoolLunchHeroes.

Contact: Rosie Krueger at mary.krueger@vermont.gov if you have any questions!

If you have had any changes in your income or you are waiting to receive unemployment, I would like to encourage all families who are not on free and reduced meal benefits to apply. You may apply for free and reduced meal benefits through the Infinite Campus Parent portal by selecting More and Meal Benefits. The link to Campus Parent is below.

https://wcsu32vt.infinitecampus.org/campus/portal/parents/washington.jsp

We are also happy to mail you a hard copy of the form if you prefer. Please email wcsufram@u32.org.

Thank you,

Michelle Ksepka

WCUUSD Free and Reduced Application Manager

One easy way for identity thieves to snatch personal information is when new drivers, in their excitement to show off their licenses, post photos of them on social media.

The Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles plans to create a “Safe Selfie Zone” at all locations for new drivers to stand in front of and have their picture taken without holding up a permit or license. A contest to design the Safe Selfie Zone is open to all Vermont high-school students.

Contest guidelines and a printable poster are on the DMV website.

Good Evening,

The Porthos 8th graders have been working hard to learn more about the American Civil Rights Movement (1950's and 1960's) in both Language Arts and Social Studies. They are currently working to produce a museum exhibit that demonstrates their learning and knowledge about a part of the Movement that interested them. They are also creating shadow boxes as a visual representation of the book, Warriors Don't Cry that they are reading in ELA.

As a part of the project, we will have a Night at the Museum on Monday, April 29th in the U-32 Cafeteria. At this event, they will showcase their museum exhibit AND shadowbox to friends, family and community members in the cafeteria. Visitors will have the opportunity to look at their work and learn more about this important time in US history.

The event will go from 6:00-7:00pm and we would like to invite community members to attend to see their work. It is important for them to have an authentic audience so your support is appreciated.

In February I shared with you that WCSU Central Office employees decided to participate in PBIS (Positive Behavioral Interventions & Supports) in support of the work our schools are doing using these methods.

One of the tools used with PBIS is to set an attainable and fun goal, publically recognize desirable behaviors that go toward meeting that goal, and then celebrate reaching that goal. The Central Office goal was 150 bananas in honor of the office mascot Bob the Minion (because Minions love bananas) and from the look of what I found in the office today, I will soon be heading out to our schools to take selfies with the kids.

I am really excited about showing the kids another way Central Office supports them. I am proud of our office for the work they have put into recognizing the good in their coworkers.

~Bill Kimball, Superintendent

U-32 budget approved by five towns

The Times Argus | March 06, 2018

STAFF REPORT
EAST MONTPELIER — Voters in the five-town, six-school Washington Central Supervisory Union easily approved the $14.8 million budget for U-32 Middle and High School during Tuesday’s town meetings.

Ballots cast in Berlin, Calais, East Montpelier, Middlesex and Worcester were collected, co-mingled and counted after the polls closed at 7 p.m. in each community. Superintendent Bill Kimball said the combined result reflected voters’ decision to pass the budget for the East Montpelier-based middle and high school, 1,183-786.

The budget calls for a spending increase of $528,112, or 3.69 percent, but after accounting for anticipated revenue it will require raising $459,468 in additional taxes, an increase of 3.21 percent.

A Message from the School Board:

Public Forum on school start times in WCSU

March 26, 2018 6:00-8:00pm at U-32

The research is clear, but what should we do with it?

Are you a teacher who has students falling asleep in your class? Are you a parent struggling to get your high school student up in the morning (and to sleep at night)? Numerous studies and articles have entered the public domain over the last 20 years and even the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) states that older students should start school later and younger students should start school earlier. A list of articles and studies on this topic is located on our website: https://www.wcsu32.org/domain/260. Please explore this topic and join us for a conversation with the WCSU School Start Times Committee and superintendent Bill Kimball. We look forward to the conversation!
